bestBHT.bht: The principle that the blesser is superior to him whom he blesses holds good in a blessing given with divine authority. Christ's blessing exemplifies this, as it is divinely efficient in working its purport. It is an admitted point about which there can be no dispute that the one who blesses is greater than the one who is blessed. Melchisedec's act of blessing Abraham showcases this, as it implies superiority of rank. The writer of Hebrews asserts a self-evident truth that the act of pronouncing a blessing implies a higher honor and authority.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The principle that the blesser is superior to him whom he blesses, holds good only in a blessing given with divine authority.
Not merely a prayerful wish, but one that is divinely efficient in working its purport.
Albert Barnes: And without all contradiction - It is an admitted principle; a point about which there can be no dispute.
The act of pronouncing a blessing is understood to imply superiority of rank, age, or station.
The word 'less' here means the one of inferior rank; who is less in office, honor, or age.
Marvin Vincent: Without all contradiction [χωρις πασης αντιλογιας] . Asserting a principle which no one thinks of questioning : it is the less who is blessed, and the greater who blesses.
John Calvin: This blessing mentioned by the Apostle was a symbol of greater authority.
The blessing of the priest, while it is a divine work, is also an evidence of a higher honor.
Melchisedec, in blessing Abraham, assumed to himself a higher dignity.
Philip Schaff: And beyond all contradiction (or without any contradiction), what gives a blessing is greater, (is raised above) what receives it.
Melchisedec is greater than Abraham, the possessor of the promises, for he adds even to the blessings of him who for all men and by all men is so richly blessed.
The exalted founder and head of the covenant people is inferior, even in the hour of his triumph, to the still more exalted and mysterious personage who is at once priest and king.
Archibald T. Robertson: The writer makes a parenthetical generalization."
The article and neuter adjective (το ελασσον, the less, υπο του κρειττονος, by the better), a regular Greek idiom.
John Gill: And without all contradiction the less is blessed of the greater."
This is a self-evident truth, and is undeniable; it admits of no controversy, and cannot be gainsaid."
He that blesseth is greater in that respect than he that is blessed by him.
John Wesley: The less is blessed — Authoritatively, of the greater.

bhtAttempts.bht: The principle that the blesser is superior to him whom he blesses holds good in a blessing given with divine authority. It is not merely a prayerful wish, but one that is divinely efficient in working its purport. Christ's blessing is a prime example of this. The writer of Hebrews asserts a principle about which there can be no dispute: the one who blesses is greater than the one who is blessed. This is a self-evident truth that cannot be gainsaid, as the act of pronouncing a blessing implies superiority of rank, age, or station. Melchisedec is a prime example of this, as he blessed Abraham, assuming for himself a higher dignity.

The principle that the blesser is superior to him whom he blesses holds good in a blessing given with divine authority. Christ's blessing exemplifies this, as it is divinely efficient in working its purport. It is an admitted point about which there can be no dispute that the one who blesses is greater than the one who is blessed. Melchisedec's act of blessing Abraham showcases this, as it implies superiority of rank. The writer of Hebrews asserts a self-evident truth that the act of pronouncing a blessing implies a higher honor and authority.

The principle that the blesser is superior to him whom he blesses holds good in a blessing given with divine authority. Christ's blessing is a prime example of this, as it is divinely efficient in working its purport. The writer of Hebrews asserts a principle about which there can be no dispute: the one who blesses is greater than the one who is blessed. This is a self-evident truth that cannot be gainsaid, as the act of pronouncing a blessing implies superiority of rank, age, or station. Melchisedec is a prime example of this, as he blessed Abraham, assuming for himself a higher dignity.

In a blessing given with divine authority, the principle that the blesser is superior to the one who is blessed holds true. Christ's blessing, a testament to its divinely efficient nature, exemplifies this. The writer of Hebrews asserts an undeniable truth: the one who blesses is greater than the one who receives the blessing. This self-evident principle is universally accepted, as the act of pronouncing a blessing implies superiority in rank, age, or position. Melchisedec, by blessing Abraham, assumes a higher dignity, showcasing the authority of the blesser over the blessed.

In a blessing given with divine authority, the principle that the blesser is superior to the one who is blessed holds true. Christ's blessing exemplifies this, as it is divinely efficient in its purpose. The writer of Hebrews asserts an indisputable truth: the one who blesses is greater than the one who receives the blessing. Melchisedec's act of blessing Abraham serves as an example, demonstrating that the blesser assumes a higher dignity. Pronouncing a blessing signifies a position of higher rank, age, or station.
